grammar_rules.description: Bambara subject pronouns are generally invariable and precede the aspect marker or verb.
Object pronouns often appear directly before the verb in SOV structures. They are mostly identical to subject pronouns.
Possessive determiners precede the noun they modify. The particle 'ka' marks possession.
grammar_rules.pattern: Pronoun + ka + Noun (e.g., n ka so)

grammar_rules.description: Demonstratives often follow the noun. 'nin' indicates proximity, 'o'/'wo' indicate distance.
Indefinite pronouns refer to non-specific entities. Reciprocal pronouns indicate 'each other'.

The standard plural marker '-w' is suffixed to nouns, adjectives, determiners, pronouns, participles, and proper nouns. A rarer plural marker '-lu'/'-nu' (PL2, often based on nasality) exists, sometimes seen in specific contexts like songs.
grammar_rules.pattern: X + w (Standard PL) / X + lu/nu (Rare PL2)

grammar_rules.description: Bambara often lacks explicit articles. Definiteness/specificity can be marked by context, demonstratives (nin/o), or numerals (kelen for 'a certain').

examples.english: There is a house / There are houses.
There is one house / a certain house.

grammar_rules.description: No grammatical gender. Sex is specified by compounding with 'cɛ' (male) or 'muso' (female/feminine) for animate beings or sometimes concepts.

Completed actions use the auxiliary 'ye' (positive) or 'ma' (negative) after the subject for transitive verbs. Intransitive verbs often take a suffix '-ra'/'-la'/'-na' (PFV.INTR), with the form depending on the final sound of the verb stem (nasal, glide, other).
grammar_rules.pattern: S + ye/ma + O + V (Transitive Aux) / S + V-(ra/la/na) (Intransitive Suffix)

examples.english: I did not buy a house.

examples.bambara: A man na / A ma na.

grammar_rules.description: Ongoing, future, or habitual actions use the auxiliary 'bɛ' (positive) or 'tɛ' (negative) placed after the subject. A progressive aspect can also be marked with the suffix '-la'/'-na' (PROG), conditioned by nasality.
grammar_rules.pattern: S + bɛ/tɛ + (O) + V (Aux) / S + V-(la/na) (Prog Suffix - often combines with Aux)

examples.english: I am going / I will go / I go.
He/she is working / will work / works.
I am not going / I will not go / I don't go.

grammar_rules.description: The marker 'ka' is used after the subject for subjunctive mood (desire, obligation, purpose) or to introduce infinitival clauses.

examples.english: He/she should come / Let him/her come.

examples.bambara: N b'a fɛ n ka taa.
A ye na ka an dɛmɛ.

grammar_rules.description: Imperative uses the verb stem alone (singular). The plural uses 'aw ka' + verb stem.
Bambara uses different copulas: 'don' for identification/focus, 'ye...ye' for predication (quality/state/equivalence), 'bɛ/tɛ' for location/existence.
Adjectives/Qualificative Verbs (vq) typically follow the noun or function as the main predicate using the 'ye...ye' copula structure. Some derive into adjectives using '-man'.
grammar_rules.pattern: Noun + Adj/vq OR Noun + ye + Adj/vq + ye

grammar_rules.description: Basic sentence order is typically Subject-(Aux)-Object-Verb-(Postposition) (S-Aux-O-V-PP).

examples.english: He/she is going to the market.

grammar_rules.description: Postpositions follow nouns or noun phrases to indicate location, direction, possession, instrument, manner, etc.

examples.english: with me / near me / by me

grammar_rules.description: Negation is primarily marked by replacing positive aspect markers: 'ye' becomes 'ma' (Perfective Negative), 'bɛ' becomes 'tɛ' (Imperfective Negative). 'tɛ' is also used for negative existence/location.
grammar_rules.pattern: S + ma + O + V (PFV.NEG) / S + tɛ + O + V (IPFV.NEG)

examples.english: I am not eating/will not eat peanuts.
He/she is not working/will not work.

grammar_rules.description: The suffix '-nin' (DIM) creates a diminutive form (small, young, dear). The suffix '-ba' (AUGM) creates an augmentative form (large, important, adult). Applicable to nouns, adjectives, participles.
The suffix '-ya' (ABSTR) forms abstract nouns from nouns, adjectives, participles, or verbs, indicating a quality, state, or condition.
The suffix '-li'/'-ni' (NMLZ), conditioned by nasality, forms action nouns (gerunds) from verbs. Often combines with 'kɛ' (to do) or other nouns.

Suffixes '-baga' or '-baa' (AG.OCC) form agent nouns (doer of an action) from verbs or nominalized verbs (-li/-ni). '-tɔ' (CONV) can form agent/characteristic nouns. '-la'/'-na' (AG.PRM) can also form agent nouns (prominent agent).
grammar_rules.pattern: V/N + baga/baa / V + tɔ / V + la/na

grammar_rules.description: Various suffixes form participles from verbs: '-nen'/'-len' (PTCP.RES - resultative/past participle), '-bali' (PTCP.PRIV - lacking/unable), '-ta' (PTCP.POT - potential/able), '-tɔ' (CONV - often agentive/characteristic).
grammar_rules.pattern: V + nen/len / V + bali / V + ta / V + tɔ

grammar_rules.description: Includes: '-lama'/'-nama' (STAT - having the quality of), '-ma' (COM - accompanied by), '-ntan' (PRIV - without), '-ka' (GENT - origin/belonging to, on proper nouns), '-la'/'-na' (LOC - locative, on proper nouns), '-lan'/'-nan' (INSTR - instrument).

Verbs can take prefixes like 'lá-' (CAUS - causative), 'mà-' (SUPER - superlative/excessive), 'rɔ́-' (IN - inessive/in), 'sɔ̀-' (EN - ??? likely causative/introductive). Suffixes include '-ma' (DIR - directional) and '-ra'/'-la'/'-na' (OPT2 - optative mood).

examples.english: to put in / to make enter

grammar_rules.description: Bambara frequently forms new words by compounding existing ones. Common patterns include N+N, V+N, N+V, N+Adj, N+PP+N, V+NMLZ+N, etc. The meaning is often compositional but can become lexicalized.
Reduplication (repeating a word or stem, sometimes with a hyphen) is common for verbs, adjectives, and adverbs to indicate intensity, repetition, distribution, or plurality.

examples.english: to get up → to get up repeatedly / all get up

grammar_rules.description: Ordinals are formed by adding the suffix '-nan' (or '-n' in some varieties) to the cardinal number. The price marker '-la'/'-na' (PRIX) can be added to a number.
